Super Blood Hockey (personally might have called it Super Bloody Hockey, to be a little more catchy), is a satirical pixelated rendition of the old school (my school) of classic NES Hockey games.  This game is definitely good humored, for example, referees are MOST laughable, since they are only there to be added obsticles ;)  The players themselves look like a bunch of 6 year olds learning hockey for the first time.  This is what definitely adds to its charm!

It is beautifully stylized, with its cutesy classic pixel art design, aesthetically a playful classic masterpiece (the pixelated TV is a nice touch)!  The first thing that stood out to me is the pixelated throwback graphical design!  It really takes me back, but offers a more satirical and cutesy version of the old NES hockey games.  The point of my curated list is to explore the artistry of design via limited pixels and resolution, so definitely a thumbs UP here :)  

The music too is well done (by that I mean poorly done, well).  There are a few guttural notes that I would personally have done without...No need to reproduce all such limitations ;)


There are 4 modes to the game: Tutorial, Exibition, Tournament & Challenge (having 5 different challenges within) and 5 difficulties: Easy, Medium, Hard, Very Hard & Pro (Seems a bit excessive and not very grandular)...The tutorial seemed to predict that this was going to be a tough as nails games.  Frankly, I found Easy, VERY if not, too difficult!  I personally play, enjoy and am pretty successful with many tough as nails games.

The game offers a team of 4 players and a goalie (except in some challenge modes), with the option of selecting from a set of team mates with different stats.  I think for those of us who are NOT real hockey buffs, they should include a little bio for each, so we can have a better understanding of how best to balance our teams.

Just like the good old days of local co-ops that were implemented by way of sitting on the same couch with multiple controllers, so too can you play with your friends.  This is quaint, but I don't know how practical in today's age.  I think an online co-op/competition would be more ideal and suited to connecting players.  Having both options would have been most flexible.


Playing on EASY mode, it very difficult...I even felt insulted, because the tutorial talks about people quitting and here I am "complaining."  Even with the decent controls, the computer can collectively use its players much better than I can.  It would seem that the trick to making goals is not in the aim or power, rather to spam the goalie until it goes in (which is how the computer scores most of their points).  

I felt that this was more an element of luck, than acquired skill.  Power shots seem to never work and simply makes the puck fly askew, losing control.  That means once at the goal, every man simply attacks the puck until success.  You cannot do this well, if at all, as a simple player playing this game!  My team mates just didn't seem to have their head in the game.  I actually found the challenge of controlling one player most enjoyable, since it is not very efficient to control all four at the goal.

Personally, I used to be into these "simulated" sports games on the NES (my brother had NES Hockey and I had Blades of Steel), but they are not as fun to me anymore, though this has been a nice experience.  Ironically, I wasn't into platforming back then and have really came to love them now, so obviously tastes change over time.  I really love tough as nails, when the game play is fun and not monotonous, but I don't feel in control of this game at its current difficulty curve.

At $8 it is not a bad value...Not so much for me at this current difficulty setting :(  I can see playing though a bit, but not sure there is replay value for me over time (we will see).  

I can suggest it for the die hard hockey fan or for the nostaligia of what this games very successfully reminds us of (In a very fun and playful way).  Maybe with an updated AI for the players team.  Of course I have not had a chance to play along with other humans either, which I think competing would be more balanced and maybe co-op would level the playing field. I haven’t played a lot of hockey video games, or really many sports games in general in recent times, but I have to say that that Super Blood Hockey gave me a good perspective on how entertaining they can be even with conventional sports.  Sure it’s no Rocket League, and it’s not going to be even remotely comparable to the actual rules and nuance of hockey, but it has some of the same allure of classics like NFL Blitz and Mario Strikers.  

[h1]Bringing back the thumb pain[/h1]

Everything about Super Blood Hockey has a nostalgic tinge to it.  From the graphics and sound, to the music, and even the wonderful thumb pain you’d get when you were handling your controller a little too hard try to make sure your character was going as fast as possible.  It looks and feels like it could be on the Super Nintendo without a hiccup and given it only has four action buttons (shoot, pass, check, and change character), it could even work with the controller.  At the start, it plays out much like any hockey game, except with five players instead of six, and you face off just as you would in normal hockey game, but it doesn’t take long for the chaos to begin.  Much like the aforementioned arcadey sports games, you can smash your opponent’s players at any time with no direct consequences.  Even though there is a referee on the ice at all times, he’s just another character to be shoved around with impunity.  The only time there is a reaction to your reckless violence, is when your repeated checks start even more violence and a fight breaks out.  Then every player starts attacking one another until one side’s entire team is down.  Once this occurs, the losing team has a player laying on the ice for a while bleeding and wiggling around uncontrollably.  This creates this game’s equivalent of a power play.  

Outside of these mechanics, the rest of the game is straightforward.  Much like any hockey game, you can charge up your shots and passes by holding the shot button.  However here, if they hit a player other than the goalie, they can easily knock them down for a short period of time – which can give you a more open shot.  You also stand to score more often by quickly passing and shooting between players.  Things only really start to change when you introduce some of the modifiers in challenge mode that affect many aspects of the game.

[h1]I think 24 is too many…[/h1]

I had to check out the 12 vs 12 mode, and as expected, it adds an impressive amount of anarchy to the already thoroughly chaotic gameplay.  When the first fight broke out, the ice was a sea of blood and twitching players.   Truly magnificent, but generally unplayable.  Other challenge modes unlock the ability to use different modifiers in the core portion of the game including harder AI.  However, as I did try to play the game on the hardest available AI, I can say that it seemed as though it changed little from the normal difficulty since both seemed fairly tough all around.  If nothing else, this adds some variety in the gameplay and keeps it playable even if you’ve tired of a (relatively) normal hockey game.

[h1]A hockey game for the everyman[/h1]

There’s not a lot that can be said about such a simple game, but that’s part of what makes it appealing.   It’s very accessible to people unfamiliar with the nuances of the sport of hockey, but still entertaining enough to keep just about anyone interested for some time.  It’s an easy game to recommend for a wide audience, though I think with online multiplayer it would really be on the next level.

Let’s get it out of the way, Super Blood Hockey is a pure blast of arcade action. Loren Lemcke has managed to capture the arcade feel of some classic games and distil it into a modern formula. Super Blood Hockey is pretty much summed up in its title; this is an arcade style ice hockey game with a strong focus on hitting people in the face, bereft of any repercussions.
In the game you get to choose from several different teams (Russia, Canada etc.) and after choosing your team you then select the types of player which form up your squad. Sniper (great at shooting but can get knocked down easily) enforcers (which can take a few hits but are slow on the ice) and a couple of others which add a level of simplistic tactics to the game that are fun to mess around with to see what suits your style of play.
The graphics in the game are pleasantly chunky and hark back to the 16-bit era with the added bonus of being extremely smooth. One of Super Blood Hockey’s strong points is how it takes a solid formula and irons out the limitations placed upon previous iterations by the technology available at the time. The gameplay is fluid and the weight of the players and movement of the puck feels ‘right’, which can be a deal-breaker in these types of games, if not handled correctly.  
A lot of people will remember Ice Hockey on the NES, which is a game to which Super Blood Hockey owes a pint or two (of type ‘O’ negative) in the aesthetics department. The music, which is very much rooted in the NES-era, is incredibly catchy and the title screen of a city at night reminded me of the Streets of Rage intro (good).
The controls in the game are just pure pick up and play. The shoulder buttons flick between players on the ice, X controls the power of your shot, A is the same for your pass and B is the attack button (you’ll use this A LOT). When the match starts, you’ll be battering your opponents in no time, spraying geysers of blood all over the shop (all the while unlocking Steam achievements like ‘ruptured lung and ‘brain damage’). However much pain you unleash on the ice, there aren’t any lasting effects so the pace of the action stays high all the way through the match with nothing  slowing down the constant pixelated gushing of blood.
Super Blood Hockey has a few different game modes, exhibition, tournament and also a challenge mode which, when completed unlocks greyed-out options in the settings that add extra touches to the game such as adjusting the weight of the puck etc. The challenges are TOUGH and consist of situations such as winning a match with a manually-controlled goalie, succeeding in a match where you are outnumbered by 8-4 players etc. (one of the options which I immediately ramped RIGHT up was raising the level of blood spilled in-game to preposterous amounts. Any vampires in the arena were loosening their ties, let me tell you!).
Whilst these optional alterations are nice additions to have, I feel that this is really a multiplayer game at heart. From what I can see, all of the teams are identical beyond their colours; the only differential comes into play with the previously mentioned player types. This is an arcade style game with a heavy focus on dip in and out local multiplayer gameplay, which to me is timeless. The game supports up to four-player local play which is absolutely perfect for the kind of game this is. Vibes I got from Super Blood Hockey were Brutal Sports Football on the Amiga for its approach to comical violence over deep strategic gameplay (Brutal Sports Football is one of my favourite Amiga games) Speedball 2 for the fluidity and Instantly accessible gameplay and also the hugely underrated Wrecked on the PlayStation 3 for its 4-player fun factor timelessness.
Beyond its arcade-action charms, if I had to pick up any negatives, it would be the lack of variety in the game. The single-player mode I can imagine isn’t as much fun as multiplayer but to me that’s not a drawback as it’s not the main pull of the game. All the best multi-player games can be a bit lonely or dull in single-player modes. In fact, I recall reading a 43% review of the aforementioned ‘Wrecked’ when to me, it’s clearly one of the best and most addictive 4-player games on the PlayStation 3. In that review, the sole focus was on the lack of modes for single-player which I didn’t pick up on at all. Another thing I’ve noticed is the difficulty in one player matches due to the AI in the game which, at the time of writing this is being addressed in a patch.
 
Super Blood Hockey  does its thing well, it has neat touches of humour with a bonkers Zamboni driver, matches that sometimes break into all out brawls and a referee that clearly doesn’t need to be there but I’m glad he is…so that I can punch him in the face. The developer seems to be adding extra patches and changes on a daily basis which is promising as they seem to be responding positively to user feedback and acting on suggestions decisively.
As I’ve mentioned, maybe there isn’t enough depth here for some people and would that be solved by the Brutal Sports-like addition of weapons & energy bars? Perhaps if different arenas, a dash button or special moves were available it would add to the longevity? But at under a fiver, if you have a few friends who come around for some drinks and gaming this is definitely an essential purchase.
 
A quick shout out to my local ice hockey team the Cardiff Demons whose star player is the drummer from my band Old Samuel! Rest assured we will be playing this game together very soon…..and If I win, I’ll never let him forget it.

34476080.developer_response:
Hi,

Sorry your experience wasn't more positive.

There are actually many very good reasons to lock the game at 60 fps. In the case of SBH, it provides consistency and accuracy to the physics engine. When it doesn't run at a constant speed it can cause issues like tunneling and other unpredictable behavior.

Creating a solution to have a physics engine run on a separate thread out of sync with the normal game logic thread is an incredibly involved task that large AAA companies have been struggling with to solve. The folks that made Skyrim and Dark Souls, for example, didn't have the resource to fix this. If large AAA studios with hundreds of people can't come up with a solution to this, then I have no chance as a single person. 

Also another consideration is for a replay system. A constant framerate allows me to record inputs over a period of time and then play them back and get the same outputs, within a deterministic physics simulation.

A third consideration is for the purpose of online multiplayer. In order to sync a deterministic physics simulation over a network, you need to record physics inputs consistently over a period of time, so time-stamped packets of data can be sent to the client to have the same physics simulation result in equal ouputs on a client computer.

Locking the game at 60 fps is the correct move for a variety of reasons. I assure you I didn't just do it "because".

Loren

[code][h1]Полноценный обзор со скриншотами вы можете прочитать здесь: [url=https://dreamsofgenesisgaming.wordpress.com/2017/08/24/super-blood-hockey/] Dreams of Genesis Gaming: Super Blood Hockey[/url][/h1][/code]

Super Blood Hockey - действительно мясистый симулятор хоккея (привет от старых добрых пиксельных игр, которые я так сильно любил во времена Денди, ага как будто у меня выбор был...). Эту игру разрабатывает лишь один человек, что несомненно придает уважения.

[h1][i]ОЛДСКУЛ И ОЩУЩЕНИЯ ОТ ИГРЫ[/i][/h1]
Не так давно я обозревал игру под названием Old Time Hockey, разработчики которого обещали вернуть игроков в золотые времена аркадного хоккея. Игра получилась мягко скажем не очень, простая, однообразная и скучная. Но не так давно вышел SBH, о котором я даже не догадывался вплоть до релиза в стиме.И что я могу сказать о этой игре в двух словах? ЭТО ПРОСТО АХ… кхм… ОФИГЕННО!!! Настолько шикарного возвращения в детство в современных играх найти практически невозможно. Абсолютно все аспекты, будь то атмосфера, геймплей или графика, просто кричат: “Эй, чувак, мы тут ностальгию завезли!”. Порог входа в игру действительно очень низкий, практически с первого матча можно понять игровую механику и навешать люлей компьютерным болванчикам. Если вы любили играть в стандартный хоккей на Денди или на Сеге, чего ты ждешь чувак? Бросай читать обзоры и беги покупать игру, поверь ты не пожалеешь, ибо игра пропитана настолько олдскульной атмосферой, что буквально начинаешь улыбаться. Приведу вам пример: “У меня действительно был плохой день, проблемы на работе и прочая фигня, думал во что бы сыграть? Решил зайти в хоккей, ибо нужно делать обзор, да и просто любопытно было, что там один разработчик смог сделать. Сразу же после первого матча я смеялся от переизбытка насилия и хардкора на хоккейном поле, а ведь я играл на легком уровне”. Кстати, на счет уровня сложности, если вы попробуете режим Pro, то вернуться снова на Нормальный будет действительно тяжело, ибо хардкор и кровавое месиво, что происходит на поле не описать не в одном обзоре, такое нужно лишь пережить самому.

[h1][i]ГЕЙМПЛЕЙ[/i][/h1]
Геймплейная часть в игре довольно мясистая. По большому счету управление контролируется всего тремя клавишами: Удар, Пас, Отбить врагу почки. Но насколько же это весело во время самой игры. Естественно удержать своего персонажа на льду довольно сложно и заранее выбранная вами позиция может сыграть с вами в плохую шутку. Вы думаете забить гол в таком пиксельном хоккее - это обыденное дело? А вот фиг вам. Даже на простом уровне вратарь соперников стоит как крепость, нужно продумывать не хилые комбинации распасовки и неожиданных ударов, чтобы застать вратаря врасплох. Но и это еще не все, если перейти на хард мод (Pro), можно понять насколько же сама игра хардкорна (скупая слеза олдскульщика скотилась по лицу Думгая). Если вы уже почувствовали себя настоящим профи в обычной игре, даже на максимальном уровне, добро пожаловать на состязания. В них существует несколько особых режимов, такие как: 4 против 8 (мы играем 4-мя игроками, а против нас 8), Один из всех (есть возможность играть лишь одним игроком, без переключения), Пол веса (облегченные игроки, вас сбить с ног - раз плюнуть), ну и самый мой любимый: 12 против 12 (хард мод - и хоккейное поле превращается в Кошмары на улице Вязов). Один из грандиозных плюсов игры - это нет правил. Нет пробросов, фолов и прочих мелочей, которые приостанавливают хаотичное действие на поле. Ну а вишенкой на тортике - является вакханалия во время массовой драки команды на команду. И если вам кажется, что 8 игроков бьются как уличные псы… мой вам совет - опробуйте режим 12 на 12, вот где начинается настоящая кровавая баня!

[h1][i]ГРАФИКА И ЗВУКИ[/i][/h1]
Большинство современных проектов пытаются навязать шикарный визуальный ряд, делая упор именно на зрительный контакт игрока с игровым миром. Большинству это прощается и не взирая на убогий сюжет и незамысловатый геймплей игра хавается (пример: серия игр КОД, Батлфилд, Фоллаут 4 и другие). Разработчики, которые не могут себе позволить дорогостоящие движки, или же просто не могут разобраться в графическом движке Юнити и прочих движков, предпочитают делать игру в стиле псевдопиксель. Иногда это смотрится действительно глупо и неуместно, особенно когда есть шикарный сюжет и современный подход к геймплею, но графическая составляющая настолько проста, что игрокам кажется разработчики просто спустили все на тормозах. В данном проекте - пиксельная графика является неотъемлемой частью как геймплея так и атмосферы, ведь невозможно создать олдскульную игру с современной графикой, хотя разработчики Old Time Hockey и пытались. Лорен Ремке (разработчик этой игры) выбрал верный путь надавить на ностальгические чувства игроков. Что касается звуковой составляющей она на довольно неплохом уровне, но это касается лишь звуков на хоккейном поле. Музыкальная тема выбрана довольно неплохо, но уже через час игры просто начинает бесить. Очень жаль, что разработчиком был выбран лишь один трек, довольно много существует бесплатных 8-ми битных композиторов, которые размещают свои композиции в свободном доступе, но увы разработчик не посчитал нужным заморачиваться по этому поводу.

[h1][i]ПЛЮСЫ И МИНУСЫ ИГРЫ[/i][/h1]
Плюсы:
+ Игра пропитана духом олдскула
+ Геймплей довольно простой, но уж очень увлекательный
+ 8-ми и 16-ти битная атмосфера
+ Реиграбельность
+ Красочная пиксельная графика
+ Возможность игры 12 на 12 (мясо чистой воды)

Минусы:
- Музыкальная тема очень быстро приедается
- Нет разнообразия в игровых моделях хоккеистов

Super Blood Hockey - предназначена в первую очередь для старперов (таких, как и я), ведь она насквозь пропитана той самой ламповой атмосферой. Для любителей аркадного Сеговского и Дендивского хоккея - маст хэв. Оценка 9 из 10.

[u]What is it?[/u]
Did you play the NES/ Famicom disk Nintendo Ice hockey game? 
Loren Lemcke certainly did and his title borrows heavily from the 1988 sports sim. If you never played this Nintendo game it has since been rereleased on the Virtual console on both Wii and WiiU. (2006 & 2014)
Quite simply you are given a team with 4 players with a choice of 3 different classes, a heavy fighter, a skinny shooter and a middle one. These teams differ by their colours and represent several countries.
This is local multiplayer Ice hockey with a referee who doesn’t do anything when the players beat each other up. 

[u] What makes it different? [/u]
It has been nearly 30 years since the original release and although he has kept the nice pixel art style with some fitting chiptune (composed by Shawn Dalley) Loren has made some welcome updates and additions. First of all he has made this 2 player game into a 4 (or 5) player game with the much more ergonomically designed Xbox controllers. 
(It appears a 5th player can join in with keyboard.) 
Loren has added some crazy challenge modes to add play time into the formula which will also grants unlockable modes. The unlockables include a manual goalie mode, no swapping mode and adjustable puck elasticity, puck friction and player weight. 
He has also added a tournament mode where giving a ‘story of sorts’ showing failure and winning screens to each team making cute jokes about each country. 
And of course as the name implies there is added blood...Super blood! This makes a red mess over the ice and will spurt out of players who are injured in fighting.

[u] What did we like? [/u]
The 4 player local multiplayer is a welcome and necessary update to this fun little game for a new generation of gamers. The art style has been done fairly tastefully and this combined with Shawn Dalleys fitting highpaced chiptunes pushes the nostalgia button hard. Although I am not a parent I feel this will hopefully warm the hearts of many older gamers who are now parents and may want to pass on their love to their children. 
I am also quite grateful for the ability to reduce the time periods, alter the amount of blood and the removing of the icing rule. The fights have been changed and it seems quite silly and funny that the referee seems to ignore the fighting and the penalty is an injured player who doesn’t get removed from the ice.

[u] What could have being improved? [/u]
This is a hard question as it is clear Loren tried to be as faithful to the original as possible. I found that the winning and losing celebration gets a bit repetitive. Perhaps for winning animations dances, poses, group poses and for losers crying, in fighting, or similar angry animations. 
I would have also hoped to hear a bit more range from the music chosen. 
Perhaps bringing on another musician in future to give more variety?
Would this game improve due to online multiplayer? 
Would there be enough of a market to warrant doubling the development time and paying for expensive hosting costs? 
This is a high paced sports game where any interruption in gameplay can be game breaking. Although difficult, perhaps the BEST way to potentially include online multiplayer is to borrow from fighting and racing games. These games sometimes collected player data as ‘ghost’ that could seamlessly cover for any interruption in connection.
Loren has added a lot of extra content on the single player side but this game can still get a little repetitive after you’ve unlocked everything and seen the winning and losing screens.

[u] Should you play it? [/u]
Yes! It’s easy to pick up and learn, it’s well put together as well as silly and fast paced!
Give it a go and share it with your friends just like we used to.

This game is pretty much Ice Hockey on NES (graphics wise) and NHL Hitz 2003 combined into a single game. It's a fast-paced, retro, arcade hockey game. It's not as fast-paced as NHL Hitz. But, like NHL Hitz, there are no rules, penalties, or play stoppages (icing, handpass, offsides, goalie puck covering, etc.) until there is a goal or the entire arena erupts into a last-man-standing brawl. The losing team to the brawl loses a man temporarily. 

There are some things that the game doesn't communicate very well to new players. For example, goalies will always block shots if they're in position to do so (essentially, it's a hitbox check with no RNG). Once I figured that out, and after losing many, many games figuring there was a chance the goalie would miss a save, I started playing way better (one-timers are your best friend in this game). It's important to keep in mind that this is a local-multiplayer game only right now. No online matches. I'm fine with that, personally, but I know many who aren't. The only thing I'd like more right now is a franchise mode or an option to make your own team (with names) and an instant-replay feature on goals. Overall, this a great arcade game if you're a hockey fan or like really fast paced, crazy games.

Review can also be found at: https://gamefold.co.uk/super-blood-hockey-review/

Super Blood Hockey is a retro inspired hockey game (of course) that was developed by Loren Lemcke with music by chiptunist Shawn Daley.

The game officially exits beta today, I actually got the review code yesterday but have been addicted to, and still am, to The Witcher 3. I'm not sure of what the exact price will be, but going by the amount of content, it will most likely be $10.

Being a hockey game, don't expect much variety, but then again its hockey and one of the few sports I find interesting. You have standard mode/exhibition mode, tournament mode, and challenge mode. Challenge mode offers five different challenges to beat, offering special scenarios such as turbo mode or 12v12 games. The rewards for beating these are an unlockable extra option to add variety to games.

These are:

    Adjustable puck friction
    No swapping option
    Adjustable puck elasticity
    Adjustable player weights
    Manual goalie option

One extra option is already unlocked from the start, which is blood volume, the default being 100ml but you can up it to 500 or 0 if you want a bloodless game. But no one wants that.....right?

Personally, I enjoyed the manual goalie option in particular as it made me focus on yet another player, having to block incoming shots myself instead of relying on the AI to. Throwing in the no swapping option to games made them significantly harder, being able to only use one player the entire time instead of switching constantly forced me to mix things up and play more defensively, rather than just punch anyone that got in my way.

There are three different classes to use. Snipers are the lightest and hit the weakest but have the highest accuracy, enforcers hit like a goddamn freight train but have the worst aim, and playmakers are a mix of the two with the highest overall stats but only one maxed.

Another feature, and one I am glad was added, is local multiplayer. It offers the chance for not one or two, but five people to play on the same system, four on controllers and one on keyboard. More games need this damn feature.

Super Blood Hockey lovingly captures the look, feel, and sound of 8-bit and 16-bit games of old. The music by chiptune artist Shawn Daley especially makes this game, sounding like its straight from the 80's.

Finally, being a hockey game, yes, you can beat the crap out of your opponents, the fights putting the game on hold until one team emerges glorious from a sea of blood of both allies and enemies.

Either alone or with friends, the game is great for short blasts of icy bloodbaths.
